While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing electrical services to local community members.  TRân has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, TRân joined T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  TRân has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1963500 VND from T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service.  The loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  TRân plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Trường (184) is a 38 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a butcher shop.


2.  Vũ Thị Hương (166) is a 51 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


3.  T. M. Tú (187) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


About T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for T. Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the T. Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


TRân Kiều Thị T. (188) là 58 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố T. Hoá.  TRân là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 28 Nam Ngạn (17.08.28).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ điện cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  TRân thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, TRân kiếm được khoảng 2000000 VND.  Vào 2008, TRân đã tham gia T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  TRân đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,963,500 VND từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua vật tư cần thiết để cung cấp dịch vụ.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Trường (184) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t.


2.  Vũ Thị Hương (166) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


3.  T. M. Tú (187) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


Về T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo T. Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh T. Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."	
If you would like to translate the Vietnamese text above, please visit the  free online translator  offered by Vdict.com.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: 038-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Luân T. Thị, a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa, is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 38 (38 - Quảng Hưng).

Married with two school-aged children, Luân operates a family member's business venture raising cattle for sale. Luân has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 1000000 VND a month.

In 2005, Luân joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women that was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND which will be used to purchase more baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her seventh from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, and Luân plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. P. Thị Út is a 55-year-old man who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support his business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 2. T. Thị Tấn is a 64-year-old man who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support his business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 3. Lê Thị Minh is a 43-year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. 4. P. Thị Dược is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food. 5. T. Thị Oanh is a 44-year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Luân T. Thị (71) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa. Luân là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 38 (38 - Quảng Hưng). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán. Luân thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 20 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Luân kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND. Vào 2005, Luân đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Luân đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. P. Thị Út (24) là 55 tuổi nam. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. T. Thị Tấn (10) là 64 tuổi nam. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. Lê Thị Minh (89) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 4. P. Thị Dược (25) là 36 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 5. T. Thị Oanh (88) là 44 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Ganzorig

texts.en:
Ganzorig is a single father who lives with his mother and seven-year-old daughter in Khovd province in western Mongolia. His mother is retired and his daughter is an elementary school student. Ganzorig currently operates a construction material trade business out of a rented stall at the largest market in his town. There are few competing businesses at this market, and his business has seen steady growth. Ganzorig started his business in 2004 after moving to the province center in an attempt to make a better life for himself. Before, he worked as a herder in the surrounding countryside and sold his livestock to get money to start his business. 

Through the years, Ganzorig has gained much experience and grown his business. His dream is to one day open an electric home appliances store that sells goods using bank leasing. He also hopes to save money to buy his own apartment and to be able to provide for his daughter's education. Ganzorig is a very optimistic person and is working hard to achieve his dreams. He is requesting a loan of $2,350 to purchase more supplies for his construction materials trade business.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan E. is from the village of Mansabandy Alto. She is 35 years old, married, and has three infant-aged children. Joan earns most of her living by planting a harvesting rice for sale. She has just started in this business.

In 2008, Joan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation anher ability to engage in business activities. Joan has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers for her crops. Joan is requesting a new loan of $225 which will be used to invest in expanding her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand rice-growing business

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana B. is from the village of Mamanga Gamay. She is 54 years old, married, and has four adult children. Ana owns and operates a general store in which she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Ana has been engaged in her business for over two years.

In 2008, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services so she can improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ana has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Ana is requesting a new loan of $225 which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Ana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and provide working capital

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa M., 49 years old, is a proud mother of 6 children and a wife of Generoso M. who is now 57 years old. She’s proud of his sons because poverty never been a reason for them to finish their studies. Although some of them just graduated a two years course but it really an achievement for them because they do it with their self and also with the help of their parents. And now they earnings money for their living, of course they’ll also give some of it to their parents for support. But Elsa not stop there, she’s not contented on that. She wants that their salaries will only belong to them; she and her husband will find a ways for their living.

Their fist business is farming that grows through the help of loan that came from Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). This business gives them incomes that support the education of their 6 children. Now, she wants again to have a loan to ASHI for her new business, the livestock raising or the raising of pigs and goat. She will use the loan for buying another pig, goat and feeds for the pig and goat.

According to Elsa she will always be a member of ASHI, because in ASHI she will sure she can make all here dreams possible like dreaming to be a successful business woman someday. And as a member of this organization she’ll not only helping herself and her family but also the other people that need help in terms of money and support.

loans.use: To finance her livestock raising (raising of pigs, goat) business

loans.name: Elaine Gracc

texts.en:
Elaine Grac D. is from the village of Unidos. She is 25 years old. Elaine Grac is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Elaine Grac owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Elaine Grac has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elaine Grac joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elaine Grac has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Elaine Grac is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Elaine Grac from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Tracy

texts.en:
Tracy A. is from the village of Unidos. She is 25 years old and married. Tracy earns her living by planting and harvesting rice. Tracy has been engaged in her business for over three years.

In 2008, Tracy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Tracy has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Tracy is requesting a new loan of $225 which will be used to purchase fertilizers. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Tracy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Jolife

texts.en:
Jolife V. is from the village of Unidos. She is 26 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Jolife earns her living by planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years.

In 2008, Jolife joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jolife has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers. Jolife is requesting a new loan of $75 which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jolife from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies adn equipment

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en: Choeun C. is a youngest man 21 years old and married father. He was married to his wife for years ago and they have no child. He is currently owned a medium size of farmland that was inherited from his grandparents since he is still not married. He cultivates a various crops to earn a living. He also plants rice, fruit, and other vegetables which he will harvest and sell his matured productivities to buyers during the past three months after he grows. His wife stays at home to hold housework and also works on the farm actions. Recently, Choeun C. faces a small problem that he lacks some farming supply. This obstacle, he is therefore applying for a loan to purchase a cultivating machine which he uses to plow his farmland. In addition, he will rent out a new machine to other farmers for fees.

loans.use: To purchase a cultivating machine which he uses to plow his farmland

loans.name: Nor Agha Group

texts.en:
Nor Agha is the group leader of Nor Agha group. There are fore members in this group, each of whom wants to take a loan for expanding their business. There requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. Sohelah wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy new machine for her business.
Nor Agha wants to take a loan for his business of vegetable. He wants to improve for his business. Rahella wants to take a loan for her husband who has electric materials shop.Ghancha Gull wants to take a loan for her business of quilted.   
So they are all very thanking for AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company) and Kiva lenders who can support all worlds.

loans.use: their expand and progress for their business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy T. is a wife of a carpenter, Bernardo T.. She is now 55 years old with two children, Ma. Salve 21 years old and Jeffrey 18 years old, both of them are still studying. A main source of their income is through their sewing of different clothes or dressmaking business. This business start when she first joined and loan in Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). She used the loan in starting this business and as of now it is still running but needed some things to make it grow. So she decided to loan again and uses to buy some sewing accessories like thread, needle, different fabrics etc., this will make her dressmaking business more productive.

But aside from their dressmaking business, they also have farming business that runs for 25 years now. It also contributes extra income for them, so she wants to make this business continue to run. That’s why she will use the loan also for buying things that needed in farming like fertilizer, pesticides and payment for the laborer.

Mercy dreaming of having a Tailoring/Dress Shop that build in business park in San Jose, place somewhere in Antique Philippines. She dreams to have this because she wants to help not only her family but other families that needed an income to support their expenses.

loans.use: To finance her dressmaking business and also the farming business

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Mr. Chhoun S. was born in 1950. He and his wife, Heang Touch, 51, are residents of Siem Reap Province. They have five children, two of whom are single; another three are married and live away from their parents' home. Three of their children are employed; their first child is a fish seller, their second child raises pigs, and their third child is a construction worker. The couple makes a living selling fish in the local Rolosh Market, collecting fish from fishermen and using a motorcycle to transport them to where they retail the fish. Chhoun S. will be using his second loan from Kiva to add to his saving in order to buy a new motorcycle which he will uses for family's riding needs and his business operations.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle which he will uses for family's riding needs and his business operations

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok L. is a 35-year-old married woman and mother. She currently lives with her husband and her five children in her own small family home, located in the rural area of Siem Reap Province. She and her husband plant rice and vegetable crops on their own plot of land next to their house. Their first son works in construction to help support the family. Sok L.’s crop is far from a watering system, so she is requesting a loan to buy a pumping machine for irrigation.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Five years ago, 49-year-old Helen E. started making sweet peanut delicacy called “bandi”. Her mother in-law taught her how to prepare this delicacy. This business pursuit is an addition to her pig-raising business, which she began with her first loan from ASHI in 2004. The pig-raising business realizes income every four months, while her banid business generates daily income.

After years of promoting her product to her acquaintances, Helen’s “bandi“ is now in demand by people visiting the province who wish to purchase a “pasalubong” (present) to bring home to friends and colleagues. Helen is requesting a loan for supplies to make more bandi so she can supply more clients.  She dreams of using her income to rent her own stall in the market and to send her four children to the highest level of education- college.

loans.use: To produce a "bandi" (sweet peanut  delicacy) production/ sales business.

loans.name: Ahmad Qayes Group

texts.en:
Ahmad Qayes is the group leader of Ahmad Qayes group. There are five members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their business. Their requested a group loan of 60000 Afghani.  
Ahamad Qayes and M. Aedres want to take a loan for their business of cooking in restaurant. There want to buy new desk and chair for the restaurant. S. jan wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. And Amena also want to take a loan for her business of bakery. She wants to buy wood for her business. Safya want to take a loan for her  husband’s business of making bicycle. Their want to improve and develop for their business.

loans.use: their make larger their business

loans.name: Wenna

texts.en: Wenna C. lives in Mandih Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 40 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a sari sari store. Wenna has been in this business for more than three years. In 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services that can help improve her life and her ability to take advantage of business opportunities. This will be her first loan, and she will use it to improve her store. She dreams of a earning enough money to provide for a better life in the future.

loans.use: To improve a sari- sari store

loans.name: Cesinia

texts.en:
Cesinia B., 46 years old, resides at Piao, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married and is blessed with five children. Her husband is with the Philippine National Police but his income is not enough for the needs of their family, since their children are all in school.

The school tuition fees had been increased and Cesinia has to find ways on her own to support her husband. She owns a small sari-sari store started with a small amount of capital and she has been an active member of Paglaum since June 2007. She's thankful that Paglaum came to their place because she believes that it can help to put more capital into her business. She also enjoys its programs and services.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Fadhili Group

texts.en:
Namnya is a member of the Fadhili borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 50 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 8 children. Her children are 36,34,32,27,24,20,17 and 14 years old. She also cares for other 3 dependents.

Namnya has owned a food business selling vegetable for 3 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Namnya first loam from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more vegetable for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Namnya hopes to save more money, pay school fees and expand her business.

Batul is another member of the same borrower group, she also requested the loan amount 150,000 from BRAC Tanzania.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable farm

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
44-year-old Sonia Z. runs a buy and sell business selling “abaca” (fiber from abaca palm leaf used for handicraft production), and “copra” (dried coconut meat used for oil production). Since her early married life with Mario started seventeen years ago, this is the business that has provided income for the family. Because of this business, Sonia has been able to sustain the growing needs of their twin children each year.

When Sonia joined ASHI in 2002, she tried venturing into buying and selling other commodities such as rice and salt. Loans she was able to access then were used as additional capital for growing her business and helping other entrepreneurs in their village have access to marketing their products in other villages and municipalities.

Now, that harvest season for rice is starting, Sonia is requesting a loan which she will be using to finance her rice buy and sell business as well as her salt buy and sell business.

With her husband’s help in managing it, Sonia really wants her business to grow. For the financial capital needed, she has no other resource but to get it through ASHI. Her dreams of buying a lot away from the seashore where they will build a shelter that would secure them from the damage that typhoons bring, and the graduation of her children from college, depend on the success of her business and its profitability. Therefore Sonia is determined to use her loan well in the business and to expand her business further. In her previous loans, she never failed to pay her dues to ASHI on time.

loans.use: To finance a large volume of rice and salt for her buy and sell business

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is a member of the Maendeleo borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 35 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 5 children. Her children are 32,26,24,19, and 17 years old. She also cares for other 3 dependent.

Tatu has owned a charcoal business for 4 years, she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Tatu,s first loan  from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 400,000Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Tatu hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Tuinuane Group

texts.en:
Naomi is a member of the Tuinuane borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 42 year old woman, she is separated from her husband. She is a mother of 4 children. Her children are 20,18,14 and 12 years old. She also cares for other 4 dependents. 

Naomi has owned a Tailoring business for 10 years, she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Naomi`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more material for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Naomi hopes to save money, pay school fess and expand hr business.

Theddora is another member of the same borrower group, she requested the loan amount 150,000 Tsh in order to expand her fishing business.

loans.use: To buy more material

loans.name: Soneui Group

texts.en:
Soneui wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a general store. Nazia wants to take out a loan for a quilt making business. Marghli wants to take out a loan for a tailoring business. Ma Parwar wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a shop selling vegetables. Mallahli wants to take out a loan for a shop selling dry fruits.

Soneui is the leader of the Soneui Group. There are five members in this group. Each of them has requested a loan to expand their business. They have requested a group loan 70000 afghani. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who provide support around the world.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Benigna

texts.en:
At the age of 66, Benigna M. is already a widow, but continues to live and be productive for her six children: Norma, 44; Isidro, 42; Christopher, 40; Joyen, 36; Olivia, 34; and Alma, 28. Benigna’s children describe her as a hardworking mother. The thing that Benigna always kept in her mind is that she will work as long as she can for herself and for her family.

Benigna’s variety store, that sells different goods that are necessary to the people in their place, has been running for twenty-eight years. It has become the main source of their income which they can use for their expenses and to buy things that they need.

The business continued to grow after Benigna joined and obtained her first loan from Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). Now, she has asked for a loan to again improve her business. She will use he loan for buying items to sell like soft drinks, wine and different kinds of groceries. Also, she wants to use the loan for her fish buy and sell business which she started after her first loan. She will buy assorted fish to sell to her neighborhood to generate extra income.

Benigna really hopes right now that her two businesses will became stable for the family to be able to live a sumptuous but simple life.

loans.use: To finance her variety store and also her fish buy and sell business

loans.name: Shafiqa Group

texts.en:
Shafiqa wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a general store. Zarmena wants to take out a loan for a tailoring business. Sarui wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a shop selling plastics. Maki wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a shoe store.

Shafiqa is the leader of the Shafiqa Group. There are four members in this group. They each want to take out a loan to expand their business. They are requesting a group loan of 40,000 afghani. They are very happy with this loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Seyamoy Group

texts.en: Seyamoy is the leader of this group, whose four members each want to take out a loan for improving and expanding their business; They are requesting a group loan of 30000 Afghani. Seyamoy wants a loan for her tailoring business. Razya wants a loan for her bakery. Nasreyn wants a loan for her husband who has a fruit store. M. Hasham wants a loan for his medical business. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who can support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina is a member of the Uvumilivu borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 22 year old woman, she is single.

Carolina has owned a Tailoring business for 4 years, she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Carolina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Carolina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materilas for her business

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz T. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 47 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Luz owns and operates a business making and selling food, serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Luz joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Luz is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for her business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay for the tuition of her children. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for her business

loans.name: Wemael

texts.en:
Wemael is a member of the active borrower group in Sakina, Arusha, She is 45 year old woman. She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 23,20,17,14 years old.

Wemael has owned a Grocery business for 1 year, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Many people say that sometimes poverty is one of the reasons why young women and men decided to get married at their young age, they out of school nothing to do so would think to get married early. But to Lucia I. even if married to Rodney I. at an early age she never think that it just that nothing to do, she loves the man and together with him she wants to get out of poverty. Lucia now is 22 years old with two children, Sheina Marie 3 years old and Pauline Kaye only 1 year old.

Their marriage life is never been that easy, her husband is a fisherman and she in order to help her husband to get an extra income, she do the buy and sell of different kind of fish. When she first joined and loan to Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) she used this as capital for this kind of business. Now, the business contributes to their income, but she wants a much higher income so she decided to loan again to ASHI to buy another set of different things that found in the sea, that can be eaten by a typical Filipino, to sell like bangus (kind of fish that found in the sea in the Philippines), shrimps, prawn, crabs for more income.

Lucia experience a lot of hard things being a poor, so she doesn’t want to experience that by her children, that’s why now she make sure to have a savings that came from the revenue of their business for the education of her two children.

loans.use: Will be used to buy different kinds of fish to sell

Chheun will be use half of her first loan to repair her house and the rest to buy a used motor for family’s touting needs.

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị is a 43 year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. L. is the group leader of a group helped by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, each is responsible for paying back the entire loan. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm xá 15 (15).

L. is married and has three adult children. She owns and operates a butcher shop and sells in the local community. L. has been in business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5.000.000 VND a month.

L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5.152.000 VND to expand her business. The loan will be her first from SEDA. L. plans to supplement her family's income.

Other Borrowers in the group...

1. Nghiêm Thị H. (20201020055) is a 49 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

2. Nghiêm Thị M. (20201020056) is a 42 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

3. Mẫn Thị D. (20201020057) is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her furniture making business.

4. Nguyễn Thị L. (20201020058) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

----------------------------------- About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. L. Nguyễn Thị (20201020054) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. L. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Nghiêm xá 15 (15). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa phương. L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND. L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. 0 Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nghiêm Thị H. (20201020055) là 49 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Nghiêm Thị M. (20201020056) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. Mẫn Thị D. (20201020057) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. 4. Nguyễn Thị L. (20201020058) là 36 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: Invest in expanding businesses.

loans.name: Nelgrace

texts.en:
Nelgrace M. is 24 years old and married to Emanuel M., who is 37 and works as a technician. They have one lovely daughter, Shaina Mae, who is three years old. Emanuel provides them with the things that they need to get by day-to-day, but it is only enough income to meet expenses, with nothing for savings.

That is why Nelgrace decided to joined a Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). Her goal was to build a business that can augment her husband's income. Her first idea was to build a variety store, but after some research she discovered that raising pigs can generate much more income. So she applied for a loan to go into this line of work. Today, her business is doing well and supplementing the family's income. Nelgrace would like to increase her income further by buying more piglets to raise, along with feed for them to eat. 

Nelgrace hopes to earn enough money to build her own house, and is saving her extra income to make this dream come true. She is also saving to educate her daughter, because she wants her to have a better life.

loans.use: To expand her hog-raising business

loans.name: Zeboniso

texts.en:
Twelve years ago, Zeboniso started a business selling clothing. Thanks to talent and hard work, she has built a successful company which supports her four children. Over the last year, IMON International has helped Zeboniso with microfinance loans. Because she is committed to growth and successful entrepreneurship, Zeboniso has used her previous loans wisely and repaid each with a perfect credit history. Now, she is seeking a new loan of $3,000 to replace her depleted inventory. With more items to sell, she can continue expanding business and supporting her family.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which eruped soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have viable business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients, and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: R. is a 48-year-old woman, married to Soeun, age 65, and they both have given birth to three children. Two of them are married and earn a living by planting various crops on their own farmland, while other one daughter is a seamstress for garment industry. R. requests a $500 loan in order to pay the cost of having a new electricity line for family's using. With the remainder of the loan she will buy an old motor for family's driving purposes. Note: R. was not available at that time so her husband appears in the picture instead.

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.en:
Ilhom is a baker with 5 years of experience. He dedicates himself to the creation of a wide range of sweets. His business has been growing over the years with a team of people who help make the sweets and distributors who deliver it to the markets, general stores and private homes. Through his business, Ilhom has generated employment for others, even though he has only a small number of employees, he has supported them and helped them. With his profits, Ilhom would like to buy some equipment which would allow him to offer his bakery goods in the various plazas and centers of Dushanbe. Right now the costs of the business and the ingredients are high and the cost of sweets is also higher. The demand has not diminished but it's more difficult for him to buy the necessary ingredients. Ilhom is requesting a loan to purchase necessary ingredients, enabling him to produce more quantity needed to meet his customer’s  requests.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.name: Think About Me #1 Group

texts.en:
Think About Me #1 is a loan group made up of five borrowers that is led by Kumba S., who lives in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.  She is 31 years old, married and has three children, ages 6 to 12.  All of her children are in school.  Kumba also cares for one child orphaned in a recent war. Kumba was unable to attend school because it was the cultural norm for girls to rely on their husbands to provide for them, and therefore school was considered unnecessary.  She lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Kumba’s business is preparing and selling dried meat, important in Liberia since most people don’t have refrigerators. She sells the meat to farmers from her stall, in a market where she is joined by about 100 other people plying various trades.  She has been in this line of work for one year, and has applied for this loan to buy additional meat and bags to transport it in.  With increased profit, she dreams of first having a larger stall and ultimately building a more permanent shop. She also hopes to build a house for her family, and invest in the future of her children, especially by sending them to the school she was unable to attend.

loans.use: To buy meat and plastic bags to transport it in.

texts.en: Yatt T., 32 years old, married woman and is the mother of one young son. She is a local farmer who has been farming since 2000. As another source of family income comes from her husband’s selling ice-cream for kids in and around his community. Yatt T. will be using a loan to grow rice crop during this coming farming season.

loans.use: To grow rice crop during this coming farming season

loans.name: One Word Group #1

texts.en:
One Word Group #1 is made up of five borrowers and led by Abraham A., who lives in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.  He is 36 years old, married, and has four children ages 3 to ten. He also takes care of another child who was orphaned in a recent war. All of his children are in school.  Abraham is a high school graduate and lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Abraham makes a living running a pharmacy which serves nearby farmers from the main highway between Kolahu and Foya.  He has run this business for three years, and is taking out this loan to buy additional pharmaceutical products to sell to his customers.  Increased profits will make it possible for him to build a more permanent shop closer to town, build a house, and continue to provide schooling for his children.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies to sell to his customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: achat de batterie chargeur

loans.name: Alesandra

texts.en:
Since Alesandra got married to Reynaldo, she raised pigs in their backyard. Over those years, hog fattening wasn't really a business for her yet it is just a sporadic livelihood activity. She had no source of capital then to sustain her grow the activity to become a business since she had no access to credit. Her husband's irregular income being a laborer is yet insufficient for the family daily exnpenses especially of her five children who range in age from one to 13 years now. 

Alesandra wanted ever since her livelihood to become a stable source of income or to say a business that is why, In 2004, she joined ASHI to be able to get a loan for a business capital. After loaning several times in ASHI, she had proven her pledge that as a member, she will try her best to use her loan in her business and that she will be able to repay on time. Now, Alesandra requests for a much bigger amount of loan for financing her livelihood activity that turned into a business for the past years. After four months of raising her pigs, she sells them in the market and she profits as much double of the amount of her capital. With large amount of capital, she can purchase more pigs to raise and sell thus making her profit more every four months.

With the profits she will be having in her business, Alesandra wanted to send all of her children to school until they graduate from college to be able to bring themselves out of poverty in the future.

loans.use: Will be use for financing a hog fattening (pig raising) business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace C. is 35 years old and married to a businessman. She has two school-aged children. Grace has a business selling food items and is requesting a loan to open a shop. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married with six children. She lives in Mile 3 Nkwen, Cameroon. Helen and her entire family live in a one-roomed house. Helen has had to overcome many challenges in life, such as taking care of her children, especially as her husband is dead. She is responsible for paying their school fees. Helen farms crops such as cocoyams, beans and cassava. She plans to invest this loan in buying seeds, clearing the farm, paying the laborers to cultivate the farmland, and renting the farm.

This will be Helen's fourth loan from Kiva partner, GHAPE, of which she has been a member since 2004. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to its location and her reasonable prices. Moreover, with experience she is now receiving a good yield from her farm. Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family, and give them good medication whenever they sick. Another part will be put towards buying land for building a house.

About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy seeds, clear the farm, pay laborers and rent

loans.name: Help Yourself #2 Group

texts.en:
Help Yourself #2 is a group of five borrowers who live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. The group leader is B. K., a single 31-year-old mother of three children, aged 5-12, all of whom are in school. B. also cares for three children orphaned in the war. She was unable to attend school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. B. lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

B. has a retail clothing business, selling slippers, blouses, pants, skirts, headware, etc. She buys clothing wholesale from nearby Guinea and sells at a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She has run her business for 10 years and is successful because her customers like her personality and work ethic. B. is requesting a loan to increase her inventory of clothing, which sells well in the rainy season. Her dream is to grow her business so that one day she can have the biggest table in the market. With the profits from her business, B. dreams of building her own house and continuing to educate her children.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of clothing

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is a member of the Vumilia borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 40 year old woman, she is divorced and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 25,19, and 13 years old.

Hawa has owned a clothing business selling clothes 6 years. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Hawa`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 450,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Hawa hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: United Group #2

texts.en:
United Group #2 is a group of five borrowers led by Jarwolie N., living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.

Jarwolie is 29 years old and married with three children aged 1-9. She also takes care of one child who was orphaned in the war. Her eldest is in the 3rd grade. She was unable to attend school herself because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Jarwolie’s business is retail beverages, including water, juice, soft drinks, and beer which she buys locally and also imports from nearby Guinea. She sells to the farming community from her temporary market stall in the Halapoi main market, alongside approximately one hundred other vendors of various trades. She has been running her business for three years.

Jarwolie’s dream is to grow her business until she can have a much bigger stall. Her business is successful because of “the way I treat my customers”. She is taking the loan to buy inventory, in larger quantities, to meet demand. With the profits from her business she dreams of building her own house and sending her children to the university which she was denied.

loans.use: To buy juice, water and soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: C., 41 years old, is married woman and mother. She lives in the freshly area of Kampong Chhnang Province where is full of clay. She currently owns a small handicraft business; she turns clay into clayish jars for sale. She is married with five children, three of whom are married and the others are single. Her husband is a rice farmer. C. is looking for a loan as capital to allow her husband to purchase a pair of cow which he will use to alleviate his hard physical labor on the farm. This loan will provide the family with new asset.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of cow

loans.name: Azindoh

texts.en:
H. is married with three children. She lives in upper GTTC Nkwen- Cameroon.  H. and her entire family are living in a house with 3 rooms.

H. had to overcome some challenges in life such as taking care of her children; supporting her husband to take pay her children school fees

This will be Helens fourth time to receive loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2004 She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location of her business, and her reasonable prices.  Also with the experience, she is now having good profit from the business.
 
Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication when  ever they sick and will cloth her children.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients

loans.use: Buying of palm oil, rice, groundnuts, beans

loans.name: Be Serious Group

texts.en:
Be Serious is a group of five borrowers led by Tethe D.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.

Tethe is 27 years old and married with two children aged 5 and 8. She also takes care of one child orphaned in the war. Her children are all in school, the oldest in 1st grade. Tethe was unable to attend school herself because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Tethe’s business is a bakery, both producing the bread and selling it in a temporary market stall alongside the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for five years and is successful because her customers like her personality and work ethic.

Tethe is taking the loan to purchase more raw materials like flour, oil, sugar, baking powder, etc., to meet increased demand. Her dream is to grow her business so she can one day have a bigger table in the main market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business she dreams of raising her family well in her own house and sending the kids to university.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for her bakery

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
L. Nghiêm Thị (20201020043) is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. L. is the group leader of a 5-member group L. offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual L., they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm xá 03 (3).

L. is married and has 1 school-aged child. To making a living, L. owns & operates a butcher shop. The main source of income for the business comes from butchering & selling pork in the local community. L. has been engaged in this business for over 19 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid a previous L. of 2,006,000 VND from SEDA. This previous L. was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new L. of 6,944,000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The L. will be the 4th L. taken out by the borrower from SEDA. L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. Nghiêm Thị L. (20201020044) is a 26-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business in the agriculture sector, raising livestock.

2. Nguyễn Thị S. (20201020045) is a 24-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her handicraft business.

3. Nghiêm Thị Huệ (20201020046) is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her furniture making business.

4. Nguyễn Thị Lý (20201020047) is a 25-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business in the agriculture sector, raising livestock.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this L. was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


L. Nghiêm Thị (20201020043) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  L. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Nghiêm xá 03 (3).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 19 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2007, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  S. hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.006.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.944.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nghiêm Thị L. (20201020044) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Nguyễn Thị S. (20201020045) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nghệ thuật.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hàng thủ công mỹ nghệ.


3.  Nghiêm Thị Huệ (20201020046) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


4.  Nguyễn Thị Lý (20201020047) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Love Group is a group of 5 borrowers, led by Hawa K., living in Kolahu, Lofa county, Liberia. Hawa is 40 years old, married, and has 5 children aged 5–20. She also takes care of 3 children orphaned in the war. Her children are all in school, the oldest in 10th grade. Hawa was unable to attend school because although she enjoyed it the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. She lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Hawa’s business is in red palm oil, used for baking, which she buys wholesale and sells in a temporary market stall in the central Kolahu market. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because her customers like her personality and work ethic. She is taking the loan to purchase 2 large tins of palm oil, which she will re-package and sell in smaller bottles. Her dream is to grow her business so she can one day have a bigger table in the main market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Hawa dreams of raising her family well in her own house and sending the kids to university.

loans.use: Purchase 2 large tins of oil

loans.name: Muhidin

texts.en:
A. Muhidin was born in 1962 in Shahristan, where he now works as a farmer. He is married and has 3 children. His main business is agriculture, which provides him with the means to meet the needs of his family. Muhidin owns a large piece of land where he cultivates different kinds of vegetables, but due to the poor quality of the soil and the insects, he is no longer able to satisfy market demand. Very hardworking, he is asking for a loan of 3,000 somoni to buy seeds and fertilizer. The loan will greatly improve Muhidin's income and his family's living standards. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON International:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Asikafo Group

texts.en: Ama is thirty – five years old. She is married and has given birth to two children. She works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. Ama is a trader. She is the leader of a trust bank group called “Asikafo” which literally means wealthy people. Most of the members in this group are engaged in trading activities such food selling, services, clothes selling, provision store, etc. They normally sell in their community market and treks to sell in other communities as well. They procure their stocks from Accra and nearby towns. The experience some of these traders have amassed over the years has given them the urge to expand their business scope, hence the need for the loan to buy goods in bulk to realize this dream. The group leader, Ama, stands in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Tojikul

texts.en:
During last year’s growing season, Tojikul was diligent in his fertilizer and pesticide-selling venture, and was thereby able to acquire adequate income. This was used both to improve his home and to save for the children’s education expenses.

However, since he used much of the season to sell fertilizer and pesticides, his own land is now empty and derelict. This is a suitable time in the season for planting, so Tojikul has taken the initiative to resume working on his land while continuing to sell fertilizer.

To meet his goals, he has requested funds to purchase farm supplies, such as seeds and mineral fertilizer. Tojikul is optimistic that his venture will be successful. All his efforts are expended to better the family’s welfare.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, such as seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Chu's Group

texts.en:
L. Chu Thị, a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, L. operates a family member's business venture selling dried goods in her community. L. has been in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month.

L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a L. of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This L. will be L.'s first L. from SEDA. L. plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children.

L. is the leader of a six member group accessing a L. offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual L., they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Cầu Gạo 12 (12). No. 20213030020.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. Tô Thị Thư is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her clothing business. No. 20213030021. 2. Nguyễn Thị H. is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her specialized retail store. No. 20213030023. 4. Đinh Thị T. is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her specialized retail store. No. 20213030024. 5. Đỗ Thị T. is a 21-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND L. to support her specialized retail store. No. 20213030025.
