loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en: Celsa B. is from the village of Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 53 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Celsa owns and operates a sari-sari or general store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month. In 2007, Celsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Celsa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario is a resident of Barangay Palao, Solana, Cagayan. He is 46 years old and married to Marriam. They are blessed with four children: Marvin, 12 years old; Marjorie, 11 years old; Melchore, 6 years old and Marnely, 2 years old. Among their four children, three of them are already enrolled in the primary school which is located in their village.

Mario is a snack vendor inside and outside their village. He makes rice cakes and sells his products to earn a living and meet the daily needs of his family. He works very hard to give his children their educational needs.

With this, Mario wanted to request a loan of PHP 6,000 from Kiva lenders as additional business capital. His food snack vending started last 2007 and he is thankful that the business is doing well. He hopes that, through having the loan, his business will become a success for the betterment of his family.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Ernesto Jr.

texts.en: Ernesto Jr. R. is from the village of Dalapang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 32 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Ernesto Jr. owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transport services in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Ernesto Jr. joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ernesto Jr. is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle to enable him to provide better service. This loan will be his second from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children’s tuition fees and for daily needs. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle to provide better service

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is made up of three members, all residents in the rural area of Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Chea N. has been selected to be group leader by the group members.

Chea N. is 49 years old and earns a living with her husband by cultivating rice. Besides the farm work, her husband is a local veterinarian and fisherman as well. This couple was married years ago and is blessed with seven children, three of whom are married and have started new homes, while the rest of them attend school. One of their daughters works as a seamstress in a factory.

Chea N. will be using her loan as capital to allow her husband to buy more fishing equipment and to repair some broken equipment.

The other borrowers who are jointly taking this loan are:

K. is applying for a loan to buy fishing equipment for her husband’s fishing business and will use the rest of the loan to buy a battery to supply a light in her house.

P., a fish seller, is asking for a loan to enlarge her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To buy and repair fishing equipment for her husband

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia S. is from the village of Sapa-Anding, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 40 years old, is separated from her spouse, and has four school-aged children. Cecilia owns and operates a sari-sari or general store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Cecilia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to pay her children’s tuition fees. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: Sapa- Anding, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Saom's Group

texts.en:
There are two low-income people who are jointly taking this loan.

One of these people, Saom V., 39 years old, is a married mother caring for four children, all of whom go to the secondary school. Saom V. and her husband earn a living by cultivating rice. However, their current income is not enough for the family’s daily expenses.

Saom V. hopes to use the loan from HKL as capital to invest in a new suitable trade as a rice trader. She will order rice in bulk to store and then sell to gain income.

The other borrower, Mrs. Saom S., 37, sells cooking supplies and she requests a loan to grow her investment.

loans.use: To invest in a new suitable trade as a rice trader

loans.name: Sarat

texts.en:
Mr. Sarat P., age 22, is single and lives with his mother and sisters in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. He has three sisters and one brother.
 
Sarat has been a cell phone vendor for one year. He buys phones in Phnom Penh to resell at his home. He hopes to supplement his existing business by repairing phones and installing cell phone applications and MP3 and MP4 players. Through this new business he will be able to generate additional income to support his family.

Sarat is applying for his first loan of $300 to purchase a computer for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a computer for his business

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Oeun S., 50, and his wife, Mrs. Davy Samut, 44, live in a small village across the Mekong River about thirteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married for over twenty years and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of them is married and other three attend school. Mrs. Davy Samut is a farmer.

Oeun has had been a truck driver for over a year. His truck breaks down and he needs money to repair it so he is requesting a loan of $1,100 to repair his truck. He will use a part of his loan to build a restroom for his family’s use.

loans.use: To repair his truck and to build a restroom for his family

loans.name: Sokhum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhum U., age 36, and her husband, Kimheng Nhong, age 39, were married in 1997 and have one son and one daughter. Both of them attend school. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sokhum and Kimheng are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to a middleman in the village, who then in turn sells it in the Phnom Penh market. Besides weaving, Kimheng is also a farmer. 

Sokhum doesn’t have enough capital to purchase raw materials (silk and cotton thread) for her weaving business. That’s why she is requesting a loan of $400 to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun L., age 57, and her husband, Mr. Vong Voir, age 62, were married in 1982 and have nine children: five sons and four daughters. Five of the children are married and do not live in the house, one daughter is a garment factory worker, and two others attend school. The couple farms; they grow rice.

One of Thoeun’s sons has just finished his baccalaureate degree. He hopes to continue his bachelor degree at university in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, about fifteen kilometers from his house. Therefore, Thoeun is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma L. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Alma owns and operates a business raising crops, mainly planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Alma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,404 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her seventh from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreng P., 26, is a silk weaver. In the past, she used to be a garment factory worker. Her husband, Mr. Lorn Un, 38, sells recycling materials. They just have a young son and live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  

The couple has built a proper house to live because their old house broke down in some parts. But, they purchased construction materials (cement, sandstone, bricks…) on credit so Sreng is requesting her first loan of 200 USD to pay for construction materials costs.

loans.use: To pay for construction materials cost for building her house.

loans.name: Sothoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Sothoeun R., age 25 (pictured with his son), and his wife, Mrs. Saing-Eng Cheab, age 44, live on an island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2001 and have two sons and two daughters.

Sothoeun and his wife have been fishing for over ten years. He is requesting a loan of 350 USD to purchase additional fishing materials for continuing his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing materials for continuing his fishing business.

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoeun V., 39, and her husband, Mr. Pov Pork, 39, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1992 and have four children: three sons and one daughter.

The family’s main source of income comes from her husband’s business building wooden houses. Mrs. Hoeun V. stays at home to take care of her children. She is asking for her first loan of $500 in order to add to her own money to build a house where she lives.

loans.use: To add to her own money to build a house

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en: Felipa B., a resident of Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 33 years of age, married with 4 children. Three of them are already in school. Her husband is a company driver. She admit that depending so much with her husband's income is really not enough. So she thought of raising pigs at her backyard. Her future plan is to raise more pigs and dreams of owning piggery in the future.So that it can help to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs to sell

location.town: Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Mamelita

texts.en: Mamelita C. is from the village of Mohon. She is 57 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Mamelita owns and operates a "sari-sari" or general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Mamelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Mamelita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Manolita

texts.en:
Manolita Q. is from the village of Dullan. She is 65 years old. Manolita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Manolita makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Manolita has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Manolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manolita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Manolita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food items for sale. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Manolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food items for sale

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita P. is from the village of Lutao. She is 44 years old. Angelita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Angelita owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Angelita has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Angelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Angelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, such as hooks and nets

loans.name: Kunthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthy R., 26 (pictured with her son), and her husband, Mr. Leab Lorn, 37, have been married since 2003. They have a daughter and a son. Besides her children, she also has her mother living with her. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers fR. Phnom Penh City. 

Kunthy has been selling groceries for six years. She buys grocery items fR. the Phnom Penh market for resale in her village. Her husband is a wood house builder. Kunthy's grocery store is old and broken down in some places, so she is applying for her first loan of $300 to build a new one.

loans.use: To build a new grocery store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is from the village of Sta. Maria, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Mary is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Mary owns and operates a clothing sales business, buying and selling clothes to local community members. Mary has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Mary is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Mary from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and provide for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoin T., age 39, is widow with three children: two daughters and one son. All of them are in school. She lives on an island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophoin has been a silk weaver since she was 17 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh market. One of Sophoin’s daughters just finished her baccalaureate degree and she hopes continues her bachelor degree at university in Phnom Penh.

Hence Sophoin is requesting a loan of 500 to pay school fees for her daughter and she will use a part of her loan to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and pay school fees for her daughter.

loans.name: Melania

texts.en: Melania D., a resident of Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte, is 57 years old and married with seven children. Her husband is a farmer, while Melania is a food vendor. She started her business doing house to house vending. But now, with the help of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, her business is growing and she owns a sari-sari (variety retail) store. Her customers are her neighbors, relatives and friends. Her future plan is that the small sari-sari store becomes bigger and gains more customers. She also hopes that all her children will finish their studies.

loans.use: Capital for food vending and sari-sari store

location.town: Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
“To become successful in life, we must stay patient and hard working” this is the guiding principle of Marivic.  She is a hard working mother and a loving house wife of Rafael. They live peacefully in the rural community of Barangay Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao with their six children. The couple wanted to give their children the best education they could afford for them to become successful in the future and achieve their ambitions in life. Their children are in college, high school and elementary level.  

Their major source of income in the village is through farming. Her husband cultivates 1.5 hectares of farm lot where he plant rice and corn while Marivic is engage into vegetable and rice cake vending in their village as alternative source of income. With this, she would like to borrow a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP9, 000 as additional capital to further improve her vending business and to have an increase  in income.  She hopes to purchase bigger volume of vegetables and fruits that she will sell.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a member of the Active borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 48 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 27 years old.

Ester has owned a food business selling potatoes, tomatoes for 5 years, she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Ester`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits, potatoes, tomatoes.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Ester hopes to save money and expand her business

loans.use: To buy more frits, potatoes, tomatoes for sale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce G. is from the village of Biasong, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Joyce is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Joyce owns and operates a sari-sari, or general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. Joyce has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Joyce joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joyce has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Joyce is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Joyce from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is a 28-year-old woman who is married with two sons. She lives in Rakai district in Mpalm zone Kyotera town council. Her retail business is five years old. She is using the loan to buy more retail items, such as bags of sugar, rice, salt, soap, jelly, dry cells, among other items, for her business expansion. Rosemary is an active business lady whose future hope is to create a big retail/wholesale shop to serve Mpalm zone in Kyotera town council so that she can withstand the competition from other small retail businesses in Mpalm zone.

loans.use: To expand her store by increasing her stock of items

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Jesus is 55 years old, married to Carmelita and they are residing in Annayatan, Enrile, Cagayan. The couple preferred to engage in the livestock business.  They raise hogs and native chickens as their source of income.  Aside from this, they also manage a small farm lot.  

Jesus wanted to borrow loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 that will serve as additional capital to maintain their livestock business.  The amount will be used to purchased feeds supply for the growth and health of their hogs and chicken. 

Jesus said that only through patience and hard work, one can be successful. Jesus and his wife are not just patient but also both working hard to reach out their goals in life. Jesus has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns double income every time he sells his raised livestock.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Sayuni Group

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Sayuni borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 27 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 6 and 3 years old.

Joyce has owned a food business selling fruits and vegetable for 1 year, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a  monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Joyce`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits and vegetable for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money, pay school fess and expand her business.

Suzana is another member of the same borrower group, she requested the amount of 150,000 In order to expand her crops business.

loans.use: T o buy more fruits and vegetable

loans.name: Pat's Group

texts.en:
The group of borrowers consists of three people. Its leader, Mrs. Pat Y., age 48, is a mother blessed with seven children, one of them is married and lives separately and others are still living in home. She currently sells baskets that she weaves them from her home. She makes and saves over 25 sets of basket and then sends it to her husband to sell them around the community. To help be responsible for family, three of her daughters are employed as garment workers. Pat Y.’s handicraft business is going well and smoothly. She requests a loan as assistant to allow her to buy her nearby neighbor’s basket in order to better satisfy her customer’s requirements. The other two borrowers are:
C. is a basket seller, who asking for a loan to buy additional baskets to sell.
Y. is applying for a loan to purchase more raw materials to continue weaving basket.

loans.use: To buy her nearby neighbor’s basket

loans.name: Pha

texts.en:
Mr. Pha P., 37, and his wife, Mrs. Ra Thorn, 35, have been married for over 15 years. They have two children: one daughter who attends school, and one young child. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Pha and his wife have been raising ducks and chickens for almost five years. He buys them from Takeo province, which is far from his house, and after the ducks and chickens grow big enough, he sells them in his village. 

Pha is now applying for his first loan of $1,100 purchase more ducks and chickens to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more ducks and chickens

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.en:
Marcelo D. is a rice grower. He is 59 years old and has lived in Trento, Agusan Del Sur Mindanao for his entire life. He says his neighbor convinced him to join and he observed that the loan really helped his neighbor grow a sari-sari (general store) business.

He would like to ask for a loan of PHP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to finance his farm. He needs to buy farming materials as well as fertilizers to grow rice.

Receiving a loan is truly worthwhile since it is a very urgent need of his farm. He chose CEVI because he heard that CEVI has the lowest interest rate on their loans, which is 2% a month.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Frank Ttoto

texts.en: N. Frank Ttoto is a female business woman aged forty-seven years old. She is married with four children. She is the owner of Nvanugi Enterprises; a stationery shop located a long old Masaka road in Kalisizo town. She is using the loan for purchasing more stationery items and computers to cater for both internet café for surfing and computer training as a side business for more income generating. Her future hope is to accumulate profits so that she can construct a school for computer training.

loans.use: For purchasing more stationery items and computers to cater for both internet café for surfing and computer training as a side business for more income generating.

loans.name: La

texts.en:
Mrs. La B., age 30, and her husband, Mr. Soksan Mork, age 30, were married in 2003 and have a three-year-old son. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

The main source of income is from her husband’s work as a security guard. La used to be a garment factory worker, but she now stays at home to take care of her son. La’s husband hopes to supplement his existing business by driving a motor taxi. With this new business he will be able to generate additional income to support his family. La is applying for her first loan of $400 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband.

Shown in the photo is La in her house and is anticipating that her loan will be granted so she can purchase a motorcycle for her husband to start a motor taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to start a motor taxi business

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn and her family live in the village of Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 30 years old and finished her secondary level of education. She is married to Guillermo and they have three children who they want to become successful in their chosen fields. For this reason, the couple strives hard in order to support their children's educational needs.

Jovelyn is in the vending business while her husband works as a farmer. Jovelyn sells vegetables, fish and frozen foods around their village. She wants to develop her business and in line with this, she wants to borrow a loan of PHP 12,000 from Kiva lenders. Most of her income is being budgeted for the basic needs of their family and school allowance of their children. She aims to strengthen her vending business to earn a higher income and able to have a better quality of living with her family.  She is hopeful that Kiva lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny R., age 39, and her husband, Mr. Sarun Am, age 32, have been married since 1991 and have two sons. One of them is adopted and he is a policeman. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh about 17 kilometers away.

Vanny has been a farmer for 20 years. She grows rice on her farmland in the village, while her husband has been selling cows for ten years.  Vanny is requesting her first loan of $550 to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for her farming business and she will use a part of her loan to buy additional cows and oxen for her husband to sell.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide for her farming business and buy additional cows and oxen for her husband to sell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji U. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables  and is requesting a loan to stock beans and rice to sell.  Keji is 35 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. 

 With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock beans to sell

loans.name: Sayuni Group

texts.en:
Nashivai is a member of the Sayuni borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 40 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 5 children. Her children are 20,19,15,12 and 9 years old.

Nashivai has owned a food business selling  vegetable for 8 years. She works 12  hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 170,000 Tanzanian  shillings.

This is Nashivai first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she quested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits and vegetable for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Nashivai hopes to save money and expand her business.


Magreth and Luciana are also the same member of the same borrower group, they also requested the loan amount 150,000 each one in order to expand their crops  business.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetable

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
Mrs. Nat T., age 54, and her husband, Mr. Ke T., age 60, live in a small village along National Road Number Five, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1972 and have six children: one son and five daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, three daughters work in a garment factory and other two children attend school. 
 
Nat has been selling Khmer noodles for two years. Mr. Ke T. has been growing rice since 1979, and he assists his wife in the business when he is free. For the future, the couple hopes to support their children’s further education and have a job. 

Nat doesn’t have her own transportation so she is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni C. is currently in the business of selling paste, tomatoes, okra, etc., and is requesting a loan to improve on the stock.  Poni is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel and lodge. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Improve the stock of items she sells

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Mrs. Dina N., age 26, and her husband, Mr. Vanny Um, age 28, were married in 2000 and have three sons and one daughter. Two of their children are in school and other two are still young. The family lives on an island off the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Dina has been a silk weaver for three years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been driving a horse cart for ten years. 

Dina doesn’t have enough capital to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. So, she is requesting a loan of $200 to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Topista

texts.en: N. Topista is aged thirty-eight years old, she owns a supermarket located a long Zziriddamu street in Kalisizo town which mainly deals in house hold items like glasses, plates, cups, sauce pans and other items like bathing soap, sugar, drinks and various others on the retail basis. She is using the loan to purchase more goods purposely to increase on the supply and more so milk and yoghurt which are on high demand presently. Her future hope is to expand her business and accumulate profits which she will use to finish the construction of her house and then hopes to acquire a plot of land and construct rental houses for extra income generating.

loans.use: To purchase more goods purposely to increase on the supply and more so milk and yoghurt which are on high demand presently.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
“In time of crisis, trust God, and he will provide your needs,” says Teresita from Lamut, Ifugao.  She is married to Avelino and they are blessed with ten children. Despite their big family, they are still living a happy life with unity. Most of their children only finished high school because of lack of financial resources.

Teresita is in the vending business and helps her husband in maintaining their farm lot, where they are planting rice and corn. She started her own business as her way of helping her husband in providing for the growing needs of their family.  She is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP 9,000 that will greatly assist her in making her business more productive and profitable.

loans.use: Financing for vending business

loans.name: Felina

texts.en:
Felina F. grows rice. She is 59 years old and a widow, and has been a CEVI client for quite a long time now. She has workers at her farm. She pays them for their labor so they can support their individual families. She says that her rice field is such a big help because it supplies her with all her needs like food, clothing and medicines, as well as money to pay for the daily expenses in her home.

She would like to ask a loan of PHP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to finance her farming activities, like paying the laborers and buying seeds and other farming needs. 

The loan will help Felina immensely to grow her business. With her loan, she will be able to sustain her livelihood and earn more income in the future.

loans.use: To finance farming activities

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina O., a 50-year-old mother of one child, is a rice farmer. She tills and grows rice to supply her family with food, clothing and other basic needs. Currently, her family owns a 1-hectare farm. Her husband, Melchor, is the one managing their farm to ensure a bountiful harvest for the family. 

Marina is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming items like fertilizers and insecticides.

She is a new CEVI client. The reason why she chose to obtain loan with CEVI is because they offer the lowest interest rate of 2% a month.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen A. is 30 years old and the mother of 4 children, the eldest being 10 years old, who have always been her inspiration in her business. The more that she thinks of her children’s future, the more she is pressured to do more and work harder to make her business better. She owns a small rice field. This provides her income to supply her family with food, clothing and other basic needs

She would like to apply for a loan worth PHP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming supplies and pay the laborers in her farm.

This loan is truly helpful because this will not just help her with the finances but with sustaining her livelihood as well.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Lymie

texts.en:
Lymie M. is a 31-year-old mother of three children. Her eldest is 13 years old and all her children are studying in school because she wants her children to pursue their education to achieve their dreams in the future. When Lymie was young, she wanted to be a doctor, but because of poverty she was not able to go to college.

Her business is rice farming. She earns a little income from growing rice and by selling the grains to some rice traders in their village. Her income was applied to school expenses and other needs in the household.

She wants to apply for a loan of PHP 5,000. She will use the loan pay the workers and rent on farm equipment. Receiving a loan is truly worthwhile because this will help augment her income to support her family.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday C. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more stock to sell.  Sunday is twenty-nine years old and married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

About the MFI: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: buy charcoal stock to sell

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun L., 41, and her husband Mr. Bros Khvan, 35, live aL. national road number one about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1997 and have one son and two daughters. Two of their children attend school and the other stays at home. 
 
Sokhoeun has been producing rice wine and raising pigs for twelve years, a skill she learned from her parents. Her husband has been a full-time driver for two years. Sokhoeun is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to build a hall for producing rice wine and also to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To build a hall for producing rice wine and to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Eddy

texts.en: S. Eddy is thirty-four years old and married with five children. He owns the charcoal store located in Katwe, Kalisizo North that sells both wholesale and retail. He is utilizing the loan to purchase more charcoal as his stock occasionally runs out, especially during the rainy season when it is in high demand. His hope for the future is to acquire a bigger store and become the sole distributor for the whole Kalisizo town. Once the profits accumulate he hopes to open another charcoal store in town, construct a better house in the village, and send his children to better schools.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy P. is a beautician in her village in Palao, Solana, Cagayan. Her skill is very beneficial to her family because she is able to help her husband to earn a living for their family, especially for the education of their children. She is 40 years old and married to Elvy. They have four children: Vincent, 16 years old, already a college freshman; Walter, 15, a senior high school student; Brilliant, 13 years old, in second year high school; and Elvisy, 10 years old, a grade school student.

Mercy aims to send all her children to college but she is quite hesitant with that matter because of financial difficulty. However, the couple works very hard to send them to school continuously. Mercy roams house to house and sometimes in other villages to look for customers whom she could offer her pedicure/manicure service. She wants to seek financial support from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP10,000 as additional capital to buy her needed materials and beauty kit, which are very essential in her business. She hopes to generate more customers once she has a complete set of materials for her business.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Kitale

texts.en:
Kitale C. is 30 years old and married to a businessman. She has six children who all go to school. Kitale has a business selling green vegetables and oranges at the nearby market. She is requesting a loan to purchase Irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and provide food for her family.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase Irish potatoes and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: N. Victor is a 34-year-old widow with three children, all of whom are in school. She is an entrepreneur who runs a stationery shop business at Herbert Street in Masaka District. N. has been running her business for ten years. She wants a loan to purchase computers and another photocopier so that she can make more profit. N.'s future plan is to buy more computers as she has a computer center where she also does typing and printing. She will also purchase more paper for running her business.

loans.use: To purchase computers and another photocopier

loans.name: Jokudu

texts.en:
Jokudu S. is 32 years old and married to a peasant. She has five children who all go to school. Jokudu is currently in the business of selling beans and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a butchery.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: S. is a 26-year-old married mother of two school-aged children. She has built a kiosk next to her home where she sells a few cooking supplies and desserts to earn a living. As another source of family income, her husband collects or buys carving wood from forests and sells it at a profit. Recently, S. has sold nearly all the items from her stock supply. She is requesting a loan so that she can restock with a larger quantity of groceries.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of groceries to sell

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.en:
Jhony D. C. is a young farmer. He is 26 years old and is tilling the farm of his parents. Before he will decide to marry someone, he said, that he would need to have a very established rice business. Currently, he also owns a 1-hectare farm; another thing that he considers his very own as a fruit of his labors.

He needs a loan of Php 5,000 to finance his farm. He will use the loan to pay for the farm equipment that he rented as well as some of the workers who helped him prepare tha land ready for planting.

Receiving this loan could make him sustain his livelihood. He wished to have an abundant harvest to save money for his future family. He chose CEVI because it offers only 2% interest rate on its loans plus insurance coverage to all borrowers.

loans.use: farm Financing
